 Group, diamond. 
 ABSTRACT: 
 Exploration  Licence  47/1127  forms  part  of  the  Balmoral  Project,  a  diamond 
 exploration  prospect  operated  by  De  Beers  Australia  Exploration  Limited 
 (DBAE). The Balmoral Project comprises of 19 tenements within the Western 
 Pilbara region of Western Australia.  
 Exploration during this reporting period focused on follow-up stream sampling 
 in  one  anomalous  catchment.  In  the  anomalous  catchment  a  2004  sample 
 produced a chrome spinel that could have possibly derived from a kimberlitic 
 type source rock. A total of 7 samples were collected during the 2005 field 
 season  and  all  results  are  awaited.  The  majority  of  the  tenement  was  to  be 
 flown  by  airborne  magnetics  during  the  2005  field  season.  However  due  to 
 the lack of availability of airborne magnetic systems the surveying was delayed 
 until  the  1st  of  February  where  further  delays  were  experienced  through  cy-
 clone  activity  in  the  Pilbara.  The  survey  is  expected  to  be  flown  in  April 
 2006.

36.text: The area straddles the West Pilbara Granite-Greenstone Terrane (WPGGT)

37.text: and  the  Central  Pilbara  Tectonic  Zone  (CPTZ).  The  WPGGT  is  dominated

38.text: by north-easterly trending granitoid complexes, discordant greenstone belts

39.text: and numerous closely spaced easterly and northeasterly striking faults. The

40.text: CPTZ has been interpreted by Van Kranendonk (2002) as a deformation and

41.text: granite  intrusion  zone  developed  from  a  post  3300Ma  rifting  of  the  East

42.text: Pilbara Granite Greenstone Terrane. Deposition in this zone gave rise to the

43.text: Mallina Basin defined by the strike slip faulting to the north and south. The

44.text: Fortescue  Group  of  volcanics  and  associated  sedimentary  units  were

45.text: deposited  on  the  Pilbara  over  approximately  a  140Mya  period  from  the

46.text: Lower  Mt  Roe  basalts  (2763+/-13Ma)  to  the  Upper  Jeerinah  Formation

47.text: (2629+/-5Ma).  This  succession  had  a  maximum  thickness  of  6.5km  and

48.text: has  been  divided  into  seven  Formations  and  grouped  into  four  major

49.text: tectono-stratigraphic  units.  In  the  project  area  from  the  base  upwards  the

50.text: units encountered are the pre-Mount Roe sedimentary units, the Mount Roe

51.text: Basalts,  the  Hardey  Formation  sedimentary  and  felsic  to  mafic  volcanic

text:
that unconformably overly the Archaean Pilbara Craton granite-greenstones. 
 The area straddles the West Pilbara Granite-Greenstone Terrane (WPGGT) 
 and  the  Central  Pilbara  Tectonic  Zone  (CPTZ).  The  WPGGT  is  dominated 
 by north-easterly trending granitoid complexes, discordant greenstone belts 
 and numerous closely spaced easterly and northeasterly striking faults. The 
 CPTZ has been interpreted by Van Kranendonk (2002) as a deformation and 
 granite  intrusion  zone  developed  from  a  post  3300Ma  rifting  of  the  East 
 Pilbara Granite Greenstone Terrane. Deposition in this zone gave rise to the 
 Mallina Basin defined by the strike slip faulting to the north and south. The 
 Fortescue  Group  of  volcanics  and  associated  sedimentary  units  were 
 deposited  on  the  Pilbara  over  approximately  a  140Mya  period  from  the 
 Lower  Mt  Roe  basalts  (2763+/-13Ma)  to  the  Upper  Jeerinah  Formation 
 (2629+/-5Ma).  This  succession  had  a  maximum  thickness  of  6.5km  and 
 has  been  divided  into  seven  Formations  and  grouped  into  four  major 
 tectono-stratigraphic  units.  In  the  project  area  from  the  base  upwards  the 
 units encountered are the pre-Mount Roe sedimentary units, the Mount Roe 
 Basalts,  the  Hardey  Formation  sedimentary  and  felsic  to  mafic  volcanic

 Archaean  mafic  and  felsic  volcanic  piles  and  associated  sedimentary  rocks

12.text: Range’s  in  the  south  to  the  coastal  plain  in  the  north  subdivided  by  a

13.text: number of east west facing scarps. Drainages generally flow to the west-

14.text: northwest  in  the  southern  areas  and  are  northerly  flowing  in  the  northern

15.text: areas. The Hamersley Range has the highest topographic relief, Mt Elvire

16.text: (673m), and consists of predominately dissected country with north facing

17.text: scarps. These scarps define the southern boundary of the Fortescue valley,

18.text: a  generally  flat  plateau  capping  the  Chichester  Range.  The  Chichester’s,

19.text: like the Hamersley’s, are formed by gently south dipping rocks. The north

20.text: facing  scarp  of  the  Chichester  Range  defines  the  southern  coastal  plain

21.text: boundary. The coastal plain contains remnant ranges of a dissected plateau

22.text: eroded by a number of marine transgression and the large northerly flowing

23.text: rivers. The coastal plain in the project area is less than 100m above mean

27.text: hills of the Fortescue plain. The tenement is split by the westerly flowing

28.text: Fortescue  River  and  to  the  north  it  covers  part  of  Booyeema  Creek  and  in

29.text: the south part of the Macklin Creek headwaters.

 The  physiography  of  the  project  area  is  represented  by  the  Hamersley 
 Range’s  in  the  south  to  the  coastal  plain  in  the  north  subdivided  by  a 
 number of east west facing scarps. Drainages generally flow to the west-
 northwest  in  the  southern  areas  and  are  northerly  flowing  in  the  northern 
 areas. The Hamersley Range has the highest topographic relief, Mt Elvire 
 (673m), and consists of predominately dissected country with north facing 
 scarps. These scarps define the southern boundary of the Fortescue valley, 
 a  generally  flat  plateau  capping  the  Chichester  Range.  The  Chichester’s, 
 like the Hamersley’s, are formed by gently south dipping rocks. The north 
 facing  scarp  of  the  Chichester  Range  defines  the  southern  coastal  plain 
 boundary. The coastal plain contains remnant ranges of a dissected plateau 
 eroded by a number of marine transgression and the large northerly flowing 
 rivers. The coastal plain in the project area is less than 100m above mean 
 The  tenement  E47/1127  lies  above  the  coastal  plains  in  the  low  rolling 
 hills of the Fortescue plain. The tenement is split by the westerly flowing 
 Fortescue  River  and  to  the  north  it  covers  part  of  Booyeema  Creek  and  in 
 the south part of the Macklin Creek headwaters.

 The geology within the tenement E47/1127 comprises mostly exposures of 
 Kylena  Basalts  in  the  north  and  Tumbiana  volcanoclastic  sediments  in  the 
 south  which  conformably  overly  the  Kylena  Formation.  The  Tumbiana 
 Formation  contains  mainly  coastal  and  near-shore  facies  sedimentary  rocks 
 ranging  from  stromatolitic  and  clastic  carbonates,  argillite,  sandstone, 
 primary and reworked tuff and minor conglomerate; with a minor mafic lava 
 component.  The  Kylena  Formation  which  dominates  the  tenement  area 
 comprises  mainly  basalt  flows,  pillow  lavas,  fine-  to  coarse-grained  and 
 4.1  Follow-up Stream Sampling 
 A  total  of  7  follow-up  stream  samples  were  collected  as  follow-up  to  a 
 anomalous sample in tenement E47/1128 to the south which contained an 
 anomalous chrome spinel. Follow-up stream sediment sampling consisted of 
 the  excavation  of  50L  of  gravel  by  hand  from  heavy  mineral  trapsites. All 
 excavated  material  was  screened  in  the  field  to  -2mm. All  sampling  was 
 conducted with the aid of a helicopter due a lack of access tracks and rough 
 All  samples  were  freighted  to  Diamond  Laboratory  Services  in  Perth  for 
 primary  treatment  facility  which  included  sizing  and  concentrating.  The 
 acidised  concentrates  will  be  forwarded  to  the  Tawana’s  Diamond 
 Laboratory in Melbourne for secondary concentration and preparation prior 
 to being examined. Table 2 outlines the 2005 sample details.

 6.  CONCLUSION AND FORWARD WORK PROGRAMME 
 Diamond exploration over E47/1127 during the reporting period included 
 the  collection  of  7  follow-up  stream  samples  and  the  planning  of  an 
 airborne  magnetic  survey  over  76%  of  the  tenement.  The  planned 
 aeromagnetic  survey  has  been  delayed  twice,  initially  by  the  lack  of 
 availability  of  airborne  systems  and  secondly  by  several  cyclones  in  the 
 The  forward  work  programme  will  involve  the  processing  and  anomaly 
 discrimination  for  the  acquired  magnetic  data.  Magnetic  anomalies 
 generated  will  be  followed  up  on  the  ground  by  sampling  and  possibly 
 drilling. Depending upon the 2005 heavy mineral sampling results, further 
 work in these areas may involve detailed heavy mineral sampling and possibly
